projects.name: Zillow Group - Datepicker UI Component
projects.title: Datepicker UI Component
projects.description: Zillow Premier Agent’s design system, Premier Agent Experience Language (PAXL), was founded to support the product’s ongoing evolution. PAXL provides designers and engineers the foundation they need to deliver new product features quickly, while also delivering a consistent UX and brand experience to Premier Agent’s users. This past summer I joined the Premier Agent UX team as a UX Engineer intern and was given the challenge to contribute a new datepicker component for Premier Agent’s design system.

info-block-1.title: Skills
info-block-1.content: Design systems, interaction design, research + exploration, front-end dev, prototyping

sections.content: "The datepicker component allows users to select a date and capture it in a text input field. Focusing on the text field triggers the display of a calendar widget inside of a dropdown panel. The calendar acts as a visual aid to help users select a date."
Click the interactive prototype below to try it out!

sections.caption-content: Click the date field labeled 'Due date' to see the datepicker in action!

sections.content: I first conducted an audit of datepickers on Premier Agent in order to understand how they were currently being used. By examining the state of datepickers on Premier Agent, I was able to identify the component’s use cases, call out inconsistencies, and take note of any variations that need to be included.
Note: While the audit includes datepickers on mobile, my project was scoped to designing a datepicker for desktop. This is due to the standard conventions of selecting a date on iOS and Android.

Next, I researched how other design systems were utilizing datepickers through a competitive analysis. In this analysis I compared and contrasted the various datepickers’ UI, logic, and interaction flows, as this allowed me to establish a baseline of how a datepicker should appear and function.

sections.caption-content: View full size datepicker competitive research.

sections.content: Using the combined data from the audit and competitive research, I then defined design requirements for the datepicker component in the context of Premier Agent. These design requirements outlined the datepicker component’s UI, interactions, states, and use cases from a minimum viable product (MVP) and version two (V2) perspective.

sections.title: MVP Requirements
sections.content:
• • Datepickers extend functionality of date input field
  • • Calendar widget appears when user clicks on date field
  • • User can select a day on calendar widget to input desired date
  • • User can still edit the text string after selecting a date
  • • User can type in date manually
  • • User can select single date in past/future
  • • User can go to previous/next month
  • • User can jump to previous/next year

After setting the design requirements I created low and high fidelity mock-ups in order to explore possible designs. I presented my explorations through multiple ad hoc and structured reviews in order to receive feedback on the datepicker’s design. Each design review led to new iterations, which included changes such as navigation UI, color, and visual hierarchy.

To further test the datepicker’s design, I developed an in-context front-end prototype. Building the datepicker into a page on the Premier Agent app allowed me to conduct user testing on the component’s micro-interactions, ensure that it followed PAXL’s visual guidelines, and incorporate patterns from PAXL's existing CSS library.

sections.caption-content: Datepicker component in 'Tasks' page on the Premier Agent app.

sections.content: As Premier Agent evolves, new use cases for the datepicker component may emerge. Anticipating these possible contexts, I prepared documentation for future versions of the datepicker component. These resources include a development document, and redlines for a V2 datepicker and range datepicker.
With the addition of the datepicker component, the amount of time needed to populate a date field has improved by 600% (decreasing from 6 seconds to 1 second).

Datepickers minimize human error by providing users the option to select a date using a calendar widget. This visual aid decreases the cognitive load required to input a date, thus streamlining this process and greatly improving Premier Agent’s UX.
From an internal perspective, my addition of the datepicker component to PAXL also speeds up UI implementation for engineers and establishes consistency for designers.

Contributing a needed UI component to a consumer-facing product was positively motivating and challenging. I look forward to applying my deeper understanding of the architecture and strengths of design systems as I continue my design career.

I am excited for the datepicker to be live on the Premier Agent desktop app soon. Thank you to Kristen, Phil, and Anmy for mentoring me and giving me the opportunity to strengthen my skills as a UX designer and front-end developer!

projects.name: Agent Newsfeed
projects.title: Agent Newsfeed
projects.description: Zillow Group is the internet’s leading real estate marketplace. In addition to helping people browse house listings easily, Zillow Group provides real estate agents the opportunity to connect with potential homebuyers through their online real estate network and customer relationship management (CRM) platform, Zillow Premier Agent. During my internship, I had the opportunity to lead the design on a project exploring an early desktop newsfeed experience for the Premier Agent platform.

info-block-1.title: Skills
info-block-1.content: Product design + strategy, UX + feature design, research + exploration

sections.content: The Agent Newsfeed is a touchpoint where agents can effectively empower their real estate skills and quickly keep up with product updates so they can be successful with the Zillow Premier Agent program.

sections.caption-content: Final proposal for desktop newsfeed design exploration.

sections.content: To gain a better perspective on different layouts, I conducted research on various newsfeeds and product blogs. For the scope of this project, I concentrated on card layout and content hierarchy.

I began exploring newsfeed designs by building off my research and incorporating patterns that already existed in the PAXL design system. Reusing PAXL components in the newsfeed minimizes the feature’s development time, however I made sure that the design system did not constrain my exploration.

sections.caption-content: Low fidelity exploration of article preview cards.

sections.content: When discussing the newsfeed’s business goals with product managers we concluded that the newsfeed’s purpose will shift as Premier Agent develops. Since its content strategy will become more clear in the future, the newsfeed’s structure should be straightforward for the feature’s first implementation. As a result, I chose to focus my explorations on the fundamental components of a newsfeed and strayed away from complex grid layouts.

sections.title: Newsfeed Landing Exploration
sections.caption-content: Single content block layout with side nav-bar.
'New content' and 'Read before' card states with simple layout.
Single article view with simple layout.

sections.content: The newsfeed feature will give agents a space to learn more about the Premier Agent program and empower them with the information they need in order to succeed. Introducing the newsfeed within the desktop experience increases article visibility, ultimately improving user engagement on the Premier Agent CRM.

I am grateful to have been entrusted with pioneering the exploration of the desktop Agent Newsfeed feature. Designing the newsfeed while keeping research and business objectives in mind was a new and fun challenge. Being able to collaborate with diverse teams in UX, product, engineering, and more was beyond immersive and I enjoyed every moment of learning.
Thank you to my intern team for giving me the opportunity to explore my interests in product design. Your support and mentorship made my experience at Zillow Group amazing!

projects.name: BUROW
projects.title: Burow
projects.description: What makes a place feel like a home? Burow is a desktop web application that helps people find the perfect neighbourhood to suit their needs. Focusing on livability metrics including price, walkability, and school rating, Burow makes it easy to discover the ideal location to complement your lifestyle.

info-block-1.title: Roles
info-block-1.content: Lead UX + visual designer, front-end engineer

info-block-1.title: Skills
info-block-1.content: Product design, design systems, web dev, user research, brand design

info-block-2.title: Team
info-block-2.content: Aman Gupta, Emily Nguyen, Joel Sequeira

sections.content: When searching for a new place to live, popular real estate apps such as Zillow, Trulia, and Redfin first ask users for their desired location. Once selected, users can narrow down their results using metrics including price and number of bedrooms/bathrooms. Listings that catch the user’s interest can then be further researched in order to find their school rating, walkability, and more.

This user flow is intuitive for people who already have in mind a specific location they want to relocate to, however what if it were the opposite and you are trying to find the right neighbourhood for you?

To solve this problem, our team decided to reverse the user flow of standard real estate apps, allowing users to parse through neighbourhood data at a macro level. Our application sorts neighbourhoods within a city by the following criteria of price, walkability, and school rating.
The variability of these metrics can be drastic, even in close proximity neighbourhoods. Because of this, this user flow benefits users who are unfamiliar with the city they are moving to.

sections.content-1:
Existing Solution
Enter location → Receive listings → Use criteria to sort through listings
sections.content-2:
Proposed Solution
Enter city → Choose criteria → Receive neighbourhood results

sections.content: In order to empathize with our target users we interviewed participants about their home-searching experience. Based on the data collected, we drafted two storyboards with possible scenarios within the scope of our application.

sections.title: Storyboarding
sections.caption-content: First storyboard by me. Second storyboard by Joel.

sections.title: Competitive Analysis
sections.content: Zillow, Trulia, and Redfin utilize picturesque real estate photography, clean visual lines and crisp typefaces to establish a professional, trustworthy interface. This gives them a sense of credibility and safety, however at the cost of appearing apathetic and stock.

To help us explore different approaches to our solution we prototyped mobile and desktop variants of our application. Our solution needed to give users similar functionality to popular real estate apps, so we included familiar features such as price search criteria and an interactive map.

The major difference in our solution is the focus of livability criteria in the search algorithm. To reflect this, we included visualizations that bring attention to neighbourhoods that best fit the user’s selected criteria. This way areas that are a ‘best fit’ are easy to pinpoint amongst all of the search results available to the user.

Because our application does not provide listings or connect users with online real estate agencies, our team decided to switch out the professional look for a cozy, welcoming atmosphere. To produce a homey feel, we followed a theme of burrowing animals and leaned towards warm earth tones and typefaces with gentle curves.
"Burow - Dig around and find the neighbourhood that fits your needs!"

sections.title: Style Guide
sections.content: As the primary visual designer, I created color and typography standards for my team. The objective of this style guide was to encompass Burow's brand, a warm and approachable housing application, while also easing development by setting visual guidelines for us to reference.

sections.title: Illustrations
sections.caption-content: Illustrations made by Emily. Concept created together.

sections.content: Redesigning a conventional user flow allowed me to test my understanding of the design process. Shifting the perspective of our target user from a micro-view to a macro-view resulted in an application that my team did not invision at first.

Despite this, we are satisfied with the solution our application provides. Through this project I also had another opportunity to advance my design and development skills, including branding, dynamic CSS styling, and working with React.js.

projects.name: BLYSS
projects.title: Blyss
projects.description: People are constantly connected to the world around them. Personal thoughts flood social media, creating a space that revolves around sharing, leaving little breathing room for privacy. Blyss is a mobile web application where people can chronicle their thoughts, reflect on their emotions, and gain insight on their personal lifestyle patterns.

info-block-1.title: Skills
info-block-1.content: Interaction design, front-end dev, UX research, brand design

sections.content: With the help of digital devices, we have an unprecedented ability to track our behaviors, habits, and thoughts. But turning data about ourselves and our communities into valuable insights is still remarkably difficult.
Our team’s objective was to explore ways to support monitoring, reflection, and behavior change by collecting, consuming, and sharing personally relevant information.

My team interviewed three participants about their daily routines and observed their behaviors throughout the course of the day. During observation we would periodically ask our participants to reflect on a situation or activity that occurred and ask relevant follow-up questions.

"I tend to jump from one thing to the next. Sometimes I feel like I don’t have time to sit down and enjoy myself."
- Research Participant

Based on the data we collected, my team discovered that our participants were so engrossed in their daily responsibilities that they often did not take time to relax nor incorporate self-care time into their schedules.
After analyzing our user research, we refined our results and pain points into the following prompts:

• • How might we help users gain insight about themselves emotionally and mentally?
      • How can we catalog a user’s feelings in a given day?
      • How might we remind users about the activities and content that make them happy?

In order to encourage positive thinking, our solution was an application that composes an anthology of moments and media for users to reflect on, ultimately boosting their mood. Users can make posts to a personal feed that include details of how they were feeling at a certain time and any accompanying media, such as a song, photo, or video.

Because the topic of our design brief is about inciting change from personal data, we decided to include an insights page where users can view breakdowns of their moods and receive suggestions on how to boost their well being. Suggestions can range from a funny video from the day before or reminders of positive moments that happened during the week.
To further understand our target users, my team drew storyboards with possible scenarios in which our app could be used.
Building off of our storyboards, we came up with personas that represent the various needs and problems our solution is aiming to resolve.
Our paper prototype focused on the user flow and interaction of creating and viewing posts. After testing we had our users score our application using usability heuristics.
Next, we created high-fidelity wireframes based on our paper prototype to visualize the flow of our application.

Our styling approach was inspired by social media apps, such as Instagram and Twitter, so we incorporated similar design standards. Some elements we emulated are a vertical scrolling chronological feed, a bottom-navigation bar, and an interface with generous white space and one accent color.

To develop our live prototype, we utilized tools including HTML, CSS, Javascript, and Node.js (Express + Handlebars). Our goal was to implement our core functions and ensure our app was responsive and fluid.

Because Blyss’s purpose is to provide insight and self-awareness to users, we conducted an A/B test on the curated content page. The results of our tests showed that page engagement was significantly higher when we gave users the option to view all of their posts by category of emotion. We changed the page’s design to reflect this as it allowed for more transparency and flexibility, which better aligned with our app’s objective.

This project was my first in-depth experience with the UX design process. From needfinding with user interviews to iterating on prototypes, I was able to participate in all stages of the design process.

I learned that designers should watch what users do, not say and that user feedback is the most valuable tool to utilize when designing. This is because a designer’s role is to create experiences not for themselves, but for the audience they are attempting to reach. In addition, I realized the importance soft skills, such as communication and trust, when working as a team.
